raw_text: For a long sentence, generating those candidates and picking the one with the highest score is time consuming. In our approach, N-best candidates for each training example are produced with the CRF++ software (Kudo et al, 2004)
clean_text: In our approach, N-best candidates for each training example are produced with the CRF++ software (Kudo et al, 2004).

clean_text: Following Kudo et al (Kudo et al, 2004), we adapted the core engine of the CRF-based morphological analyzer, MeCab1, to our POS/PROTEIN tagging task.

raw_text: Word segmentation is the first step of natural language processing for Japanese, Chinese and Thai because they do not delimit words by white-space. Segmentation for Japanese is a successful field of re search, achieving the F-score of nearly 99% (Kudo et al, 2004)
clean_text: Segmentation for Japanese is a successful field of research, achieving the F-score of nearly 99% (Kudo et al, 2004).

raw_text: One would notice that the baseline scoreis much lower than the score previously reported regarding newspaper articles (Kudo et al, 2004)
clean_text: One would notice that the baseline score is much lower than the score previously reported regarding newspaper articles (Kudo et al, 2004).

raw_text: This area of research may be considered almost completed, as previous studies reported the F-score of nearly 99% (Kudo et al, 2004)

raw_text: We would like to note that the higher accuracy of PROPOSED in comparison with the baselines is statistically significant (p < 0.01, McNemar? s test) .The performance of the two word segmentation baselines (JUMAN and MECAB) is significantly worse in our task than in the standard word segmentation task, where nearly 99% precision and recall are reported (Kudo et al, 2004)

raw_text: To demonstrate our method, we compare to several well-known structural learning algorithms, like CRF (Kudo et al, 2004), and SVM-HMM (Joachims et al, 2009) on two well-known data, namely, CoNLL-2000 syntactic chunking, SIGHAN-3 Chinese word segmentation tasks
